questions.text: The chest x-ray of a child is given below. Which of the following is the primary defect responsible for this condition?

choices.text: Anterior deviation of the infundibular septum
Pulmonary venous connection to the SVC
Ostium secundum defect in the fossa ovalis

questions.solution:
The chest x-ray shows cardiomegaly caused by enlargement of the right atrium, giving rise to a massive box-shaped cardiac shadow. This is suggestive of Ebstein anomaly, which is caused by the downward displacement of an abnormal tricuspid valve.

Infants with severe disease present with marked cyanosis, massive cardiomegaly, and long holosystolic murmurs. Death may result from cardiac failure, hypoxemia, and pulmonary hypoplasia.

Other options:

Option B: Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF) is due to anterior deviation of the infundibular septum. It has been classically characterized by the following components:

  • Pulmonary stenosis
  • Ventricular septal defect (VSD)
  • Overriding of the aorta, and
  • Right ventricular hypertrophy (RVH)

Paroxysmal hypercyanotic attacks occur during the 1st year of life and may last from a few minutes to a few hours. The child can have shortness of breath and bluish discoloration of lips which is relieved by squatting. Chest X-ray shows "coeur en sabot" or boot-shaped heart.

Option C:  A pulmonary venous connection to the superior vena cava (SVC) is seen in total anomalous pulmonary venous return (TAPVR). It is a cyanotic congenital heart defect in which the pulmonary veins drain directly into the right atrium. On chest x-ray, supracardiac TAPVR presents with the snowman appearance of the heart.

Option D: An ostium secondum defect in the fossa ovalis is the most common site of atrial septal defects (ASD). Most ASDs are asymptomatic and are picked up during routine physical examinations. A widely fixed and split S2 is characteristic. A soft ejection systolic murmur best heard over the left upper sternal border is also commonly found.

Related Pearl: Radiological findings in some congenital heart defects

Boot shaped heart - Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF)

 

Egg on string appearance - Transposition of Great Arteries (TGA)

 

Snowman's heart appearance or figure of 8 appearance - Supracardiac TAPVC

 

Box Shaped Heart - Ebstein's Anomaly

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding neonatal resuscitation in a preterm infant?

choices.text: Delayed cord clamping is recommended in vigorous infants
Positive pressure ventilation is indicated for heart rate < 100 bpm
Initial steps of resuscitation are performed in all the cases
100% FiO2 is the initial concentration for resuscitation

questions.solution:
A slightly higher FiO2 in the range of 21-30% can be used initially in the case of preterm infants.

The preferred initial gas for neonatal resuscitation in term infants is room air. 100% FiO2 was used for neonatal resuscitation in the past but is no longer recommended due to an increased risk of hyperoxia which can decrease cerebral blood flow and generate oxygen-free radicals. the remaining algorithm for neonatal resuscitation is the same for term and preterm infants.

If the neonate does not achieve normal oxygen saturation levels within 90 seconds, increased concentrations of oxygen are administered until normal saturation levels are achieved. If pulmonary hypertension is suspected (meconium aspiration, diaphragmatic hernia), one may consider 100% oxygen as the initial gas for resuscitation. 

As soon as the baby is born, three questions are assessed -

  • Is the infant full-term?
  • Does the infant have good muscle tone?
  • Is the infant breathing or crying?

If the answer to any of these questions is no, resuscitation is initiated with the initial steps. These initial steps include - warming to maintain the normal temperature, proper positioning of the baby's airway, i.e. sniffing position with the head slightly extended, clearing of airway secretions, and tactile stimulation. Since a preterm baby is not full term initial steps of resuscitation are indicated in all preterm babies (Option C).

After the initial steps of neonatal resuscitation, the heart rate of the baby must be assessed. If the heart rate is < 100 beats per minute (bpm), positive pressure ventilation is provided along with SPO2 monitoring to ensure adequate ventilation (Option B).

Delayed cord clamping is recommended in all vigorous babies, especially preterm infants (Option A). Apart from higher hemoglobin levels, delayed cord clamping in preterm infants improves hemodynamic stability, decreases the risk of necrotizing enterocolitis and intraventricular hemorrhage, and decreases the need for transfusions and inotropic support.

questions.text: A 3-day-old neonate is brought with complaints of yellowish discoloration of the skin. The mother reports that the baby was born at 34 weeks of gestation and has a poor suckling reflex. The baby is suspected to have breastfeeding jaundice. Which of the following features is unlikely to be seen in this baby?
questions.solution:
Hyponatremic dehydration is unlikely to be seen in this baby. Babies with breastfeeding jaundice usually have hypernatremic dehydration. 

Breastfeeding jaundice occurs due to inadequate breastfeeding and usually resolves once breastfeeding is adequate. Indicators of inadequate breastfeeding in an infant include:

  • Weight loss >7-10% of birth weight
  • Lethargy (sleeping longer than 2–3 hours) (option A)
  • Delayed stooling (Less than 4 times/day)
  • Decreased urine output (urinating less than 5–7 times/day) (option C)
  • Hypernatremic dehydration
  • Inconsolable crying and increased hunger (option D)

Insufficient milk intake could be due to insufficient milk production, failure of established breastfeeding, and health conditions in the infant that prevent proper breast stimulation. Late preterms (34-36 weeks of gestation) usually have poorly developed suckling and swallowing patterns which can lead to insufficient milk syndrome. 

Breastfed neonates usually feed 8–12 times a day, with a minimum of 8 times per day. However, the neonate should be breastfed on demand.

questions.text:
A 7-year-old girl presents with a 4-month history of joint pain, morning stiffness, and swelling in the knees and ankles. She also reports eye pain and photophobia. Which of the following ILAR criteria must be met to diagnose systemic juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA)?
  1. Age at onset < 18 years
  2. Duration of disease more than 2 weeks
  3. Quotidian fever of more than 2 weeks duration for at least 3 days
  4. Arthritis in one or more joints

ILAR - International League of Associations for Rheumatology
questions.solution:
The correct answer is 3 and 4.

According to the International League of Associations for Rheumatology (ILAR) Classification of JIA, systemic JIA is defined as:

Arthritis in one or more joints, with onset below 16 years of age and persisting for at least 6 weeks, with or preceded by a fever of ≥ 2 weeks in duration that is documented to be daily (quotidian) for at least 3 days and accompanied by one or more of the following:

  • Evanescent (nonfixed) erythematous rash
  • Generalized lymph node enlargement
  • Hepatomegaly, splenomegaly, or both
  • Serositis (pericarditis, pleuritis, or peritonitis or combination of the three)

The subtypes of Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis (JIA):-

  • Oligoarthritis (4 or fewer joints) (Most common type)
  • Polyarthritis (5 or more joints) RF Positive
  • RF Negative
  • Systemic JIA
  • Psoriatic arthritis
  • Enthesitis-related arthritis
  • Undifferentiated

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is associated with normal bone age compared to chronologic age?
questions.solution:
Children with familial short stature have normal bone age compared to chronological age.

Familial short stature refers to short stature that is inherited within families. The parents are also shorter in stature, and there is usually no underlying pathology affecting growth and development. Therefore, bone age assessments are typically consistent with chronologic age in children with familial short stature.

Short stature can be defined as growth below the expected genetic potential or below -2 SD for age and sex. If a child's stature is less than -3 SD below the average for their age and gender it is more likely to indicate pathological short stature. A child's height between -2 and -3 SD is more likely due to physiological, i.e. familial or constitutional short stature.

The 2 types of normal variants of short stature are as follows:

  • Constitutional delay: Bone age < Chronological age
  • Familial short stature: Bone age = Chronological age

Bone age is more than chronological age in precocious puberty. Bone age is less than chronological age in constitutional delay, undernutrition, endocrinologic short stature, and systemic illness.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is developmental deviance seen?
questions.solution:
Developmental deviance is seen in cerebral palsy.

Developmental deviance is the acquisition of milestones in a sequence that is different from usual. Children with cerebral palsy may show early standing with support secondary to increased extensor tone.

Cerebral palsy (CP) is a static encephalopathy affecting movement and posture due to non-progressive disturbances occurring in the developing fetal brain. The subtypes of cerebral palsy include:

  • Spastic diplegia
  • Spastic quadriplegia
  • Spastic hemiplegia
  • Dyskinetic cerebral palsy

Dyskinetic/Athetoid/Choreoathetoid/Extrapyramidal CP is more commonly seen in term infants. It is likely to be associated with birth asphyxia and kernicterus in the early neonatal period. Clinical features include hypotonia with poor head control. Hypertonia with rigidity and dystonia, as well as involuntary movements, can develop in the later years. The upper limb is affected more than the lower limb. An MRI scan of the brain revealed lesions in the basal ganglia and thalamus.

Spastic diplegia is more commonly seen in premature infants due to damage to immature white matter. Periventricular leukomalacia is the most common neuropathologic finding in spastic diplegic patients.

Spastic quadriplegia is associated with ischemia of the brain and infections. MRI would reveal severe periventricular leukomalacia and multicystic cortical encephalomalacia.

Spastic hemiplegia is associated with thrombophilic disorders and infections. MRI is more sensitive than CT scans for the diagnosis.

Other options

Option B: Developmental dissociation is seen in a case of congenital hearing loss. Dissociation is defined as the acquisition of developmental milestones in various domains at differing rates e.g. isolated speech delay with normal development in other spheres, as in patients with congenital hearing loss.

Option C: Developmental regression is seen in the case of Rett syndrome. Developmental regression is progressive deterioration in mental and motor functions, causing loss of acquired milestones.

Option D: Hypoxic ischemic encephalopathy can cause global developmental delay. Global developmental delay is defined as a delay in acquiring milestones in two or more of the following domains, namely gross and fine motor, speech and language, cognition, socio-personal, and activities of daily living.

questions.text: What is the most common mutation seen in cystic fibrosis?
questions.solution:
The most common mutation in cystic fibrosis is Phe508del. 

Cystic fibrosis or mucoviscidosis is an autosomal recessive disorder with a mutation in the cystic fibrosis transmembrane regulator (CFTR) gene on chromosome 7q. The most common CFTR mutation is F508 deletion.

CFTR gene encodes for ATP-gated chloride channels in the apical membranes of epithelial cells. It regulates the flow of ions across epithelial membranes of sweat glands, respiratory airways, pancreatic ducts, etc. The defect leads to high salt concentrations in sweat and viscous luminal secretions in the respiratory and gastrointestinal tracts.

Clinical manifestations/ complications of cystic fibrosis include:
  • Sinusitis and nasal polyps
  • Respiratory - copious hyper-viscous and adherent pulmonary secretions with abnormal mucociliary clearance obstruct small and medium-sized airways leading to respiratory compromise. The disease can be further complicated by bronchiectasis and allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA).
  • Gastrointestinal - 
    • Thick and adherent exocrine secretions obstruct pancreatic ducts and impair the production and flow of digestive enzymes
    • Tissue destruction of the exocrine pancreas, with fibrotic scarring, cyst proliferation, and loss of acinar tissue - fat malabsorption, steatorrhea, fat-soluble vitamin deficiencies
    • Obstruction of intrahepatic bile ducts and parenchymal fibrosis leading to hepatic insufficiency and focal biliary cirrhosis
    • Distal intestinal obstructive syndrome in adults and meconium ileus in neonates
  • Reproductive - males have infertility due to the congenital absence of bilateral vas deferens and defective sperm transport, resulting in obstructive azoospermia. Females have infertility due to abnormalities of the reproductive tract secretions.

 The diagnosis is confirmed if both of the following criteria are met:

  • Presence of
    • Clinical symptoms affecting at least one organ system (respiratory, gastrointestinal, or genitourinary) or
    • Positive newborn screening or
    • A sibling with cystic fibrosis
  • Evidence of dysfunction of the CFTR gene by
    • Two positive sweat chloride test results were obtained on separate days or
    • Identification of two CFTR mutations by genetic testing or
    • An abnormal measurement of nasal potential difference

Cystic fibrosis requires a multidisciplinary approach to management. The correction of the defect can be via:

  • Lumacaftor, an FDA-approved drug that corrects the misfolding and reverts the Phe508del mutation defect
  • Ivacaftor potentiates CFTR channel opening and stimulates ion transport

End-stage pulmonary failure requires lung transplantation.

questions.text: A one-and-a-half-year-old child was brought to the hospital with a history of breathlessness, fever, cough, cold, and respiratory rate was 46/min. According to the WHO guidelines, which of the following, if present, is not considered a danger sign in this baby?
questions.solution:
From the given clinical picture, it can be inferred that the child has pneumonia. Chest indrawing is not considered a danger sign in this baby.

 Danger signs of pneumonia in children are: 

  • Not able to drink 
  • Persistent vomiting 
  • Convulsions, lethargic or unconscious 
  • Stridor in a calm child 
  • Severe malnutrition 

 Pneumonia is usually associated with tachypnea (increased respiratory rate). Fast breathing is defined according to age groups as:

Age of child Fast breathing RR
<2 months  >60 breaths/min
2-12 months  >50 breaths/min
1-5 years  >40 breaths/min

 The revised classification of acute respiratory infections is simplified to include only two categories of pneumonia:

  • Pneumonia- with fast breathing and/or chest indrawing, which requires home therapy with oral amoxicillin.
  • Severe pneumonia- pneumonia with any general danger sign, which requires a referral and injectable therapy.

questions.text: An infant in the neonatal intensive care unit was observed to have a minimal nasal flare, marked xiphoid retractions, intercostal retractions that were just visible, and inspiratory lag with a grunt audible with a stethoscope. What would be the Silverman Anderson score?
questions.solution:
Silverman-Anderson score of this infant would be 6. 

Silverman Anderson score is more suited for preterms with hyaline membrane disease. This score is indicative of the severity of respiratory distress. It is given as follows:

Score 0 1 2
Upper chest retraction (Chest movement) sync lag on inspiration see-saw
Lower chest retraction (Intercostal retraction) none just visible marked
Xiphoid retraction none just visible marked
Nasal dilatation none minimal marked
Grunt none stethoscope only naked ear


In the given scenario:

  • Presence of grunt audible on stethoscope- 1
  • Minimal nasal flaring- 1
  • Marked xiphoid retraction- 2
  • Intercostal retractions that were just visible- 1
  • Chest movement with inspiratory lag- 1

Total score: 6

A score of >6 indicates impending respiratory failure.

The image given below gives the scoring system for the Silverman-Anderson score.

Another score called the Downes’ Score is more comprehensive and can be applied to any gestational age and condition. Scoring is to be done every half an hour and charting is carried out to monitor progress. The parameters in Downes' scores are:

  • Respiratory rate
  • Air entry
  • Cyanosis
  • Grunting
  • Retraction

Downe’s score of >6 means impending respiratory failure.

questions.text: A term neonate is born to a primigravida with gestational diabetes. Periodic monitoring of blood glucose is done, though the baby is asymptomatic. The initial blood glucose was 25mg/dl, after which a trial of oral feed is given. The repeat blood glucose value is 35mg/dl. What is the next step in the management of this baby?
questions.solution:
In an asymptomatic baby born to a mother with gestational diabetes, if the blood glucose persists below 40mg/dl after a trial of oral feeds, the baby must be started on IV glucose infusion.

Infants of diabetic mothers are at a high risk of developing neonatal hypoglycemia. This is particularly applicable after the initial 2–3 hours of life. Blood sample is collected by heel prick. Babies showing blood glucose <40 mg/dL on a reagent strip should be treated for hypoglycemia. Since reagent strips have high false-positive rates, a confirmation of hypoglycemia by a lab test is recommended.

Neonatal hypoglycemia can be suspected when blood glucose level is <45 mg/dL. Clinically, the hypoglycemia may be asymptomatic or may manifest with a range of clinical features like stupor, tremors, cyanosis, convulsions, apneic spells, weak and high-pitched cry, lethargy, difficulty in feeding, episodes of sweating, sudden pallor, hypothermia and rarely, cardiac arrest.

In an asymptomatic baby, if the initial blood sugar is more than 20mg/dl, a trial of oral feeds is given, and blood sugar is tested after 30-45 minutes. If repeat blood sugar values are above 40 mg/dL, frequent feeding is ensured with 6 hourly monitoring of blood sugar for 48 hours. However, if blood sugar values persist below 40 m g /dL, the baby should receive an IV glucose infusion. 

If the initial blood sugar value is less than 20 mg/dL, then intravenous glucose infusion is started.

In a symptomatic baby, a bolus of 2 mL/kg of 10% dextrose should be given, followed immediately by glucose infusion at an initial rate of 6 mg/kg/min. Blood sugar is checked after 30-45 minutes and then 6 hourly. Repeat hypoglycemic episodes are treated by increasing the glucose infusion rate by 2 mg/kg/min until a maximum of 12 mg/kg/min.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presents with abdominal distension and loss of appetite. Abdominal examination reveals a large right upper quadrant mass. Laboratory evaluation shows an elevated serum alpha-fetoprotein level. Which of the following conditions is not associated with this patient's presentation?
questions.solution:
The given clinical case of a 2-year-old child presenting with abdominal distension, loss of appetite, large right upper quadrant mass, and an elevated serum alpha-fetoprotein level are suggestive of hepatoblastoma. Of the above-listed conditions, Denys-Drash syndrome is not associated with hepatoblastoma.

Denys-Drash syndrome (Option D) is associated with Wilms tumor, early-onset nephropathy, progressive renal insufficiency, and gonadal dysgenesis. There is no known association with hepatoblastoma.

Hepatoblastoma is the most common malignant liver tumor of early childhood, usually presenting in children before three years of age. It is associated with the following conditions:

  • Familial adenomatous polyposis
  • Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome
  • Aicardi syndrome
  • Trisomy 18 and other trisomies
  • Prematurity or low birthweight

Hepatoblastoma usually presents as a large right upper quadrant abdominal mass with associated abdominal distension. It is more likely to arise from the right lobe of the liver. As the disease progresses, fatigue, fever, weight loss, anorexia, vomiting, and abdominal pain may ensue.

Ultrasound of the abdomen is useful to characterize the hepatic mass and differentiate it from benign vascular lesions. CT or MRI is an accurate method to diagnose the size and extent of the tumor and for the evaluation of metastatic disease. A tissue biopsy is needed to confirm the diagnosis. The histological section shows proliferating hepatoblasts consisting of round epithelial-type cells (given below).

Management involves complete surgical resection of the primary tumor and systemic chemotherapy. A liver transplant is an option for unresectable tumors.

questions.text: A newborn presenting with hematuria and bilateral non-tender flank masses is under evaluation. Ultrasound results indicate bilateral kidney enlargement with mixed echogenicity. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis for this newborn, presenting with hematuria, bilateral flank masses, and kidneys showing mixed echogenicity on ultrasound, is polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD).

The USG image below shows mixed echogenicity of ADPKD:

Polycystic kidney disease manifests in two forms: autosomal dominant and autosomal recessive. The autosomal recessive type, ARPKD, typically appears in infancy or childhood due to mutations in the PKHD1 gene located on chromosome 6. These mutations result in defective fibrocystin protein, crucial for maintaining the primary cilia in renal collecting ducts and biliary epithelial cells. Consequently, patients develop cystic dilation of these structures.

Clinical features of ARPKD include non-tender bilateral renal masses, chronic renal failure, Potter sequence (severe in-utero renal impairment), hypertension, as well as congenital hepatic fibrosis and Caroli disease. Ultrasound examination commonly reveals bilaterally enlarged kidneys with multiple cysts and hepatic and portal fibrosis.

Other possibilities:

Option A: Wilms tumor, caused by mutations in WT1 or WT2 genes, usually presents with unilateral flank mass and hematuria. It's the most prevalent renal malignancy in childhood. The ultrasound shows a large heterogeneous tumor.

Option C: Renal cell carcinoma typically occurs in older adults and presents with hematuria, flank pain, and a palpable renal mass. The ultrasound shows a hyperechoic solid mass.

Option D: IgA nephropathy often follows respiratory or gastrointestinal infections and presents with hematuria, flank pain, and nephrotic syndrome.

questions.text: A baby born to an HIV positive mother was brought to the clinic. You suspect the baby to be infected too. Which of the following clinical features may suggest stage 1 HIV in this patient?
questions.solution:
Persistent lymphadenopathy is seen in stage 1 of AIDS in children

Presentations of clinical-stage 1 of AIDS include the following:

  • The child may be asymptomatic.
  • Persistent lymphadenopathy may be observed.

Other options:

  • Recurrent upper respiratory tract infections occur in stage 2
  • Unexplained persistent diarrhea and fever occur in stage 3

Related Pearl: Clinical stages of HIV in children/ infants

Stage 1

  • Asymptomatic
  • Persistent generalized lymphadenopathy

Stage 2

General-

  • Unexplained persistent hepatosplenomegaly
  • Recurrent or chronic upper respiratory infections (otitis media, otorrhoea, sinusitis, tonsilitis)
  • Fungal nail infections

Oral-

  • Recurrent oral ulcerations
  • Unexplained persistent parotid enlargement
  • Linear gingival erythema

Skin- 

  • Papular pruritic eruptions
  • Extensive wart virus infection
  • Extensive molluscum contagiosum
  • Herpes zoster

Stage 3

General-

  • Unexplained moderate malnutrition not adequately responding to standard therapy
  • Unexplained persistent diarrhea (14 days or more)
  • Unexplained persistent fever (above 37.6 °C intermittent or constant, for longer than one month)
  • Unexplained anemia (<8 g/dL), neutropenia (<0.5 x 109/L) or chronic thrombocytopenia (<50 × 109/L)

Oral-

  • Persistent oral candidiasis (after first 6-8 weeks of life)
  • Oral hairy leukoplakia
  • Acute necrotizing ulcerative gingivitis/periodontitis

Respiratory-

  • Pulmonary TB/ Lymph node TB
  • Severe recurrent bacterial pneumonia
  • Symptomatic lymphoid interstitial pneumonitis
  • Chronic HIV-associated lung disease including bronchiectasis

Stage 4

General-

  • Unexplained severe wasting, stunting or malnutrition not responding to standard therapy
  • Chronic herpes simplex infection; (oro-labial or cutaneous of more than one month's duration or visceral at any site)
  • Extrapulmonary TB and disseminated non-tuberculosis mycobacterial infection
  • Kaposi sarcoma
  • Oesophageal candidiasis (or candidiasis of trachea, bronchi or lungs)
  • Cytomegalovirus infection; retinitis or CMV infection affecting another organ, with onset at age over 1 month)
  • Disseminated endemic mycosis (extrapulmonary histoplasmosis, coccidioidomycosis)
  • Chronic cryptosporidiosis and isosporiasis
  • Symptomatic HIV-associated nephropathy or HIV-associated cardiomyopathy

  • Central nervous system toxoplasmosis (after one month of life)
  • HIV encephalopathy
  • Cerebral or B-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma
  • Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy
  • Extrapulmonary cryptococcosis (including meningitis)

Respiratory-

  • Pneumocystis pneumonia
  • Recurrent severe bacterial infections (e.g., empyema, pyomyositis, bone or joint infection, meningitis, but excluding pneumonia)

questions.text: A child presents with painful swelling of the parotid glands as shown in the image below. Which of the following is true regarding this condition?

choices.text: Salivary gland involvement is limited to the parotids
The patient is not infectious prior to clinical parotid enlargement
Mumps orchitis frequently leads to infertility

questions.solution:
In the given scenario the image of a child presenting with painful swelling of the parotid glands suggests the diagnosis of mumps. Meningoencephalitis can precede parotitis is true regarding mumps. 

Meningoencephalitis classically manifests 5 days after parotitis, however, it can occur before, or along with parotitis.

Other options:

Option A: Mumps virus may involve salivary glands (parotid, submandibular), CNS, pancreas, and testes.

Option B: The virus appears in saliva 7 days before to 7 days after the appearance of parotid swelling. The maximum period of infectivity is 1-2 days before 5 days after the onset of parotid swelling.  

Option D: Mumps orchitis may lead to atrophy of the testes but sterility is rare even with bilateral involvement.

questions.text: A newborn is being assessed for his gestational age. Which of the following is not a component of the neuromuscular criteria for maturity according to the expanded New Ballard score?
questions.solution:
The cubital angle is not a component of the neuromuscular criteria for maturity according to the expanded new Ballard score.

The expanded New Ballard score is used to assess the physical and neuromuscular maturity of the newborn and thereby calculate the gestational age.

  • There are six criteria each to assess physical maturity and neuromuscular maturity.
  • The physical maturity and neurologic maturity scores are added to calculate the gestational age.
  • The minimum score is -10 and the maximum score is 50.
  • It is accurate to within 2 wk of actual gestational age
  • Premature infants have low scores while post dated infants have higher scores.

Neuromuscular criteria for maturity (according to the expanded New Ballard score):

  1. Posture
  2. Square window (wrist)
  3. Arm recoil
  4. Popliteal angle
  5. Scarf sign
  6. Heel to ear

Physical criteria for maturity (according to the expanded New Ballard score):

  1. Skin
  2. Lanugo
  3. Plantar surface
  4. Breast
  5. Eye/ear
  6. Genitals - male or female

questions.text: A 1-year-old child presents with pinpoint ecchymoses around the hair follicles and multiple episodes of epistaxis. On examination, he has nodules as seen in the image given below, which are tender on palpation. All of the following radiological signs could be seen in this patient, except ____.
questions.solution:
The given clinical features of perifollicular hemorrhages and the image showing scorbutic rosary are suggestive of scurvy. The radiological sign cupping and fraying is not seen in this patient. It is seen in rickets. 

Radiological signs in scurvy include:

  • White line of Frankel: Calcified cartilage at metaphyses
  • Trummerfeld zone: Lucent metaphyseal band underlying Frankel line
  • Pelkan spur: Lateral prolongation of the white line, which is present at the cortical ends
  • Wimberger ring sign: Circular, opaque radiologic shadow surrounding epiphyseal centers of ossification

Scurvy results from the deficiency of vitamin C, which is required for the hydroxylation of lysine and proline. Hence, deficiency of vitamin C leads to defective collagen formation resulting in generalized bleeding tendencies.

Hemorrhagic manifestations of scurvy include:

  • Petechiae, purpura, ecchymoses at pressure points
  • Epistaxis
  • Gum bleeding
  • Perifollicular hemorrhages

Other manifestations are: 

  • Poor wound and fracture healing
  • Hyperkeratosis of hair follicles
  • Arthralgia and muscle weakness
  • Defective osteoid formation
  • Costo-chondral separation leading to the formation of sharply angulated tender nodules or scorbutic rosary

Related Pearl: Radiological Features of Scurvy

Radiological features of scurvy:

  • Generalised osteopenia
  • Pencil-point cortex: Cortical thinning
  • Periosteal reaction due to subperiosteal hemorrhage
  • Scorbutic rosary: Expansion of the costochondral junctions
  • Hemarthrosis
  • Wimberger ring/ Wimberger sign: Circular, opaque radiological shadow surrounding epiphyseal centers of ossification, which may result from bleeding
  • Frenkel line: Dense zone of provisional calcification 
  • Trummerfeld zone: Lucent metaphyseal band underlying Frankel line
  • Pelken spur: Metaphyseal spurs which result in cupping of the metaphysis

Related Pearl: Important Clinical Features of Rickets

Related Pearl: Radiological Features of Rickets

Radiological features of rickets:

  • Loss of provisional zone of calcification: earliest radiological finding of rickets. 
  • Delayed appearance of the epiphysis
  • Widening of growth plate: normal width of growth plate is 2-4mm. It is increased in cases of rickets due to excessive accumulation of uncalcified osteoid at the growth plate.
  • Cupping of metaphysis: normally metaphysis meets epiphysis as a smooth line of sclerosis. But in rickets the line is absent and the metaphyseal ends appear irregular and the cartilage accumulating in the growth plate creates a depression in the metaphysis causing cupping.
  • Fraying: indistinct margins of the metaphysis
  • Bowing of diaphysis, with thinning of cortices
  • In healing rickets, zone of calcification becomes denser. 

The above features are prominent at the growth plates where growth is greatest:

  • Knee: distal femur, proximal tibia
  • Wrist: especially the ulna
  • Anterior rib ends: rachitic rosary

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presented with abdominal pain, vomiting, and oliguria following chemotherapy. Investigations reveal hyperuricemia, raised creatinine levels, and hyperkalemia. Which of the following is true regarding the management of this condition?

choices.text: Urinary alkalanization with sodium bicarbonate is not recommended
Allopurinol control serum uric acid levels better than febuxostat
Rasburicase is not effective in patient with renal failure

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a 7-year-old boy presenting with abdominal pain, vomiting, and oliguria following chemotherapy and the laboratory investigations showing hyperuricemia is suggestive of tumour lysis syndrome(TLS). Urinary alkalization with sodium bicarbonate is not recommended in the treatment of TLS as it decreases the solubility of xanthine, hypoxanthine, and calcium phosphate, which potentially increases the risk of intratubular crystallization. 

Tumour lysis syndrome (TLS) is a condition that can occur spontaneously after the initiation of chemotherapy. 

During chemotherapy, the treatment kills the malignant cells, which leads to increased serum uric acid levels from the turnover of nucleic acids causing hyperuricemia. Tumor lysis results in the release of intracellular potassium, and phosphate pools, which causes hyperkalemia, and hyperphosphatemia. Increased phosphate levels lead to reciprocal depression of serum calcium/hypocalcemia. Deposition of uric acid crystals, calcium phosphate, and hyperphosphatemia leads to renal failure.

Signs and symptoms associated with TLS can develop within 12-48 hours after the initiation of chemotherapy and include:

  • Abdominal pain and distension
  • Dysuria, oliguria, flank pain and hematuria
  • Anorexia, vomiting, cramps, seizures, spasms, altered mental status, and tetany due to hypocalcemia
  • Weakness and paralysis due to hyperkalemia
  • Hemodialysis in patients refractory to medical treatment

Management of TLS includes:

  • Before starting therapy, the electrolytes should be measured and aggressive hydration should be done.
  • Allopurinol is a xanthine oxidase inhibitor that decreases the synthesis of uric acid. It should be started in TLS to prevent further accumulation of uric acid.
  • Febuxostat is a non-selective xanthine oxidase inhibitor that can be used to treat hyperuricemia. It does not require dose calculations and can be used in patients with mildly decreased renal function. Febuxostat controlled serum uric acid levels better than allopurinol in patients with blood cancers at intermediate to high risk of tumor lysis syndrome (TLS). (option B)
  • Rasburicase is an enzyme that degrades uric acid. It is preferred in TLS over allopurinol to decrease the accumulation of uric acid (option D). It rapidly decreases uric acid levels within hours and also can be used in patients with renal failure. It is contraindicated in patients with G6PD deficiency, as they cannot break down hydrogen peroxide which is the end product of the urate oxidase reaction (option C).
  • If serum potassium > 6.0meq/L, serum uric acid > 10mg/dL, serum creatinine > 10mg/dL, and serum phosphate >10mg/dL or increasing symptomatic hypocalcemia, hemodialysis is the treatment option.

questions.text: All of the following statements about fetal circulation are true except:

choices.text: Inferior vena cava carries oxygenated blood
Ductus venosus connects umbilical artery to inferior vena cava
Ductus arteriosus shunts blood from pulmonary artery to aorta

questions.solution:
All of the above statements about fetal circulation are true except option B. Ductus venosus connects the umbilical vein (not umbilical artery) to the inferior vena cava (IVC).

The fetal circulation is distinctly different from adult circulation. It allows the fetus to receive oxygenated blood from the placenta as the lungs do not provide a gaseous exchange. This is due to the vasoconstriction of the pulmonary vessels that divert the blood away from the pulmonary circulation. The umbilical cord consists of 2 umbilical arteries and 1 umbilical vein along with blood vessels of the placenta. The structures unique to the fetus for circulation are ductus venosus, foramen ovale, and ductus arteriosus.

Mechanism:

About 50% of the oxygenated blood from the umbilical vein enters hepatic circulation. The rest of the oxygenated blood from the umbilical vein bypasses the liver and enters the IVC via the ductus venosus. 

The right atrium receives the oxygenated blood from the IVC (option A) and superior vena cava (less oxygenated). The right atrial pressure is more than the left atrial pressure resulting in the major flow of blood from the right atrium to the left atrium via the foramen ovale. The blood from the left atrium flows to the left ventricle. The upper part of the fetal body (coronaries, cerebral arteries, and upper extremities) is exclusively perfused by the left ventricle via the ascending aorta.

Some oxygenated blood from the right atrium also enters the right ventricle which is ejected into the pulmonary artery. Only 5% of the right ventricular outflow enters the lung due to the high pressure from vasoconstriction of the pulmonary arteries (Option C). The major portion of this blood bypasses the lung and flows from the pulmonary artery into the descending aorta via the ductus arteriosus (Option D). This blood provides perfusion to the lower body and the placental flow via the 2 umbilical arteries.

Given below is a flowchart of fetal circulation.

Related Pearl: Concepts of Fetal Circulation

Concept 1:

Oxygenated blood from placenta to the fetus via the left umbilical vein.

Concept 2:

Most of the umbilical venous blood shunts via the ductus venosus to the inferior vena cava and gets mixed with deoxygenated blood from the lower part of the body and liver.

Concept 3:

One-third of blood from the inferior vena cava is directly pumped to the left atrium across the foramen ovale; then to the left ventricle; and ejected from there into the ascending aorta, where it supplies the upper body and the brain.

Concept 4:

A major portion of blood enters the right ventricle, mixes with blood from the superior vena cava, and ejects into the pulmonary trunk.

Concept 5:

Ductus arteriosus bypasses the lungs, and hence, a major portion pumps into the descending aorta to perfuse the lower part of the body and the umbilical arteries carry blood to the placenta for oxygenation.

questions.text: A 2-day-old neonate was admitted to the NICU after he was observed to have repetitive, rhythmic movement in unilateral upper and lower limbs, which cannot be suppressed by restraint. There is no sustained eye deviation noted. What's the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The 2-day-old neonate exhibiting repetitive, rhythmic movement in unilateral upper and lower limbs which cannot be suppressed by restraint and does not show any sustained eye deviation is suggestive of a focal clonic type of neonatal seizure. 

A focal clonic seizure is characterised by multiple, repetitive, rhythmic contractions of muscle groups of the limbs, face, or trunk, maybe unifocal or multifocal. It may occur synchronously or asynchronously in muscle groups on one side of the body. It may occur simultaneously but asynchronously on both sides. It cannot be suppressed by restraint. It has the best prognosis.

Other options: 

Option A: Focal tonic seizures are characterised by sustained posturing of a single limb, sustained asymmetrical posturing of the trunk, and sustained eye deviation. They cannot be provoked by stimulation or suppressed by restraint.

Option C: Myoclonic seizures are random, single, rapid muscle contractions of the limbs, face, or trunk. They are not repetitive or may recur at a slow rate. They can be generalized, focal, or fragmentary. They can be provoked by stimulation. It has the worst prognosis.

Option D: Subtle seizures include transient eye deviations, nystagmus, blinking, mouthing, abnormal extremity movements (rowing, swimming, cycling, pedalling), fluctuations in heart rate, hypertension episodes, and apnea. They are more common in preterm than in term babies.

questions.text: The following finding is seen in a 3-day-old newborn. Which of the following statements is false regarding this condition?

choices.text: The palms and soles are usually spared
It is a benign finding in newborns
They are neutrophil laden sterile lesions
Lesions usually persists for only a week

questions.solution:
The lesions seen in the given image indicate erythema toxicum. The false statement is option C as these lesions predominantly contain eosinophils.

Erythema toxicum is a benign finding in a newborn that resolves on its own (Option B). It presents with papular lesions on an erythematous base, predominantly distributed over the trunk and face. The palms and soles are usually spared (Option A). This condition is seen 1-3 days after birth and may persist for 1 week (Option D). The lesions resolve spontaneously and do not require any treatment.

Related Pearl: Benign findings in a newborn

1. Erythema toxicum – small, white papules on an erythematous base that usually present on the face, trunk, and extremities. They contain eosinophils and may persist for a week. 

 

2. Mongolian spots – Slate-blue, demarcated areas of pigmentation seen over the buttocks and back. This is also called dermal melanocytosis. 

 

3. Pustular melanosis – Benign lesions seen predominantly in black neonates, contains neutrophils, and is present at birth as vesiculopustular eruption around the chin, neck, back, extremities, palms and soles.

 

4. Sebaceous Hyperplasia - White-Yellow papules on nose of a newborn due to hyperplastic sebaceous glands

 

5. Milia - Pearly opalescent white, epidermal inclusion cysts usually over the face.

 

6. Epstein Pearls - nests of epithelial cells, that appear as whitish/yellowish spots on hard palate. Usually, resolve by 3 months.

 

7. Cutis Marmorata - Transient lacy reticular vascular pattern of skin caused due to exaggerated physiologic vasomotor response on exposure to low environmental temperature.

 

8. Sucking Blisters - Solitary or scattered superficial bullae present at birth on the upper limbs of infants, which are caused by vigorous sucking on the affected part in-utero.

 

9. Salmon patch or naevus simplex - Small, ill-defined, pink-coloured macules commonly seen over glabella, eyelids, upper lip, and nuchal area, which develop due to vascular ectasia.

 

10. Harlequin colour change - A transient, well-demarcated colour change, with one half of the body displaying erythema and the other half pallor, usually occurring between two and five days of age.

 

11. Vaginal bleeding in the newborn at 2–3 days of age and enlargement and secretion of the breasts in both sexes.

12. Hymenal tags

13. Physiological phimosis

14. Conjunctival hemorrhage

15. Peeling of skin (especially in post terms)

Necrotizing enterocolitis is the most common life-threatening gastrointestinal disorder in the newborn period. It is characterized by various degrees of mucosal or transmural inflammation and necrosis of the intestinal tract. It most commonly affects the distal ileum and proximal colon. 

Three major risk factors implicated:

  • Prematurity is the greatest risk factor
  • Formula feeding
  • Bacterial colonization of the intestine

Incidence and mortality increase with decreasing birth weight and gestational age. It usually presents within the 2nd or 3rd week of life with abdominal distension and tenderness, feed intolerance, and occult/gross blood in the stool. Systemic features include hypotension, bradycardia, lethargy, and temperature instability.

Diagnosis can be made with a plain abdominal x-ray. The important signs are :

  • Pneumatosis intestinalis- air in the bowel wall is diagnostic, and corresponds to stage IIA.
  • Portal vein gas is a sign of severe disease and corresponds to stage IIB.
  • Pneumoperitoneum indicates perforation and corresponds to stage IIIB.

The given x-ray shows pneumatosis intestinalis (black arrows). It is seen as a characteristic train-track lucency appearance within the bowel wall due to the gas produced by bacteria.

Management of NEC includes supportive measures, nil per oral, nasogastric decompression, intravenous fluids, broad-spectrum antibiotics, and inotropic support if indicated. Perforation is an absolute indication of surgery. The most effective preventive strategy is the use of human milk. Prebiotics and synbiotics can be used with variable efficacy in the use of probiotics.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presents with pallor and abdominal distension. His hemoglobin is found to be 7 g/dL. The electrophoresis pattern shows HbA 45%, HbA2 5%, and HbF 30%. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
HbA 45%, HbA2 5%, and HbF 30% are seen on hemoglobin electrophoresis in Beta-thalassemia intermedia. 

Alpha- and beta-thalassemia are inherited disorders in which there is reduced production of alpha-globin or beta-globin chains, respectively. This leads to the precipitation of the excess (unpaired) chains, interfering with red blood cell (RBC) production and survival. Disease severity is inversely correlated with the number of functioning globin chains. Each individual carries 2 beta-chain genes and 4 alpha-chain genes.

β Thalassemia major is a clinical syndrome caused by homozygous expression of abnormal β-thalassemia genes in the form of β+/β+, β+/β0, or β0/β0. The etiology is similar to that described above. Briefly, there is the complete absence or only minimal synthesis of the β-globin chain. The predominant type of hemoglobin is HbF, with very low HbA levels and normal to mildly increased HbA2 levels. HbA2 (5% or more); HbF (up to 95%); no HbA. 

β-thalassemia intermedia is a genetically heterogeneous β-thalassemia variant of moderate severity. This category includes milder variants of β+/β+ or β+/β0-thalassemia. HbA2 (4% or more); HbF (up to 50%)

β-thalassemia minor (trait) is a clinical syndrome caused by the heterozygous expression of one normal (β) gene and one abnormal β-thalassemia (β0/+) gene. It can either be present as β+/β or as β0/β. HbA2 (4% or more); HbF (up to 5%).

  • Beta +- thalassemia: The most common cause is splicing mutation.

questions.text:
You are educating a group of young mothers at the village health camp about breastfeeding. Which of the following statements are true regarding the components of breastmilk?
  1. Polyunsaturated fatty acids help in nerve myelination.
  2. Lactoferrin has antimicrobial action.
  3. Breast milk is deficient in vitamin C.
  4. Exclusive breastfeeding causes vitamin D deficiency.
questions.solution:
The true statements are statements 1, 2, and 4.

Polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFA) in breast milk help in nerve myelination. Lactoferrin helps in immunomodulation, iron chelation, and antimicrobial action. Breastmilk is deficient in vitamin D and exclusively breastfed infants can develop vitamin D deficiency unless adequately supplemented. Breast milk is a rich source of vitamin C and is found in higher levels than in cow milk.

PUFA like docosahexenoic acid (DHA) present in breast milk plays an important role in the growth and nervous system development. Human milk contains taurine and cysteine which are required for neural development. The epidermal growth factor present in breast milk helps in intestinal cell maturation and repair. The other components present in breast milk are secretory IgA, transforming growth factor, nerve growth factor, platelet-activating factor, bifidus factor, and glutathione peroxidase. Breastmilk has high water content and infants who are exclusively breastfed need not be supplemented with water during their first few months of life. 

The protein content in breast milk is low compared to animal milk. Whey constitutes 70-80% of breast milk's protein content. The predominant whey protein is α-lactalbumin in human milk and β-globulin in cow milk.  Lactose is found in high concentrations in breastmilk and its component galactose is necessary for the formation of galactocerebrosides. It also promotes the growth of lactobacilli. Breastfed infants are at a lower risk of dying from serious gastrointestinal and respiratory illnesses.

Breast milk is deficient in vitamin K and infants have to be supplemented with the same to prevent hemorrhagic disease of the newborn.

questions.text: A newborn with features of wrinkled skin, small low-set ears, flat nose and limb anomalies presented with anuria, respiratory distress and cyanosis. Imaging revealed pulmonary hypoplasia. Which of the following renal abnormality is associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, a newborn with features of wrinkled skin, small low-set ears and a flat nose are characteristic of potter facies. The presence of anuria, respiratory distress, cyanosis and imaging revealing pulmonary hypoplasia, is characteristic of Potter syndrome. Bilateral renal agenesis will be seen in this condition.

Potter's syndrome is characterized by the triad of:

  • Renal agenesis
  • Oligohydramnios
  • Pulmonary hypoplasia

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl has undergone brain surgery for a suprasellar tumor that was causing her headaches and visual impairment. Histopathological examination revealed a large and heterogeneous tumor with solid and cystic components containing a cholesterol-rich, thick, brownish-yellow fluid comparable to machine oil. All of the following are true about this type of tumor, except?

choices.text: They have a high recurrence rate

questions.solution:
This clinical vignette of a lesion in the suprasellar lesion in a child,  with solid and cystic components and a cholesterol-rich, thick, brownish-yellow fluid described as similar to machine oil, is suggestive of craniopharyngioma which is a benign tumor. 

Craniopharyngiomas are benign tumors derived from Rathke’s pouch, a diverticulum arising from the embryonic buccal cavity, from which the anterior pituitary gland develops. It is most commonly seen in children (5–15 years); however, it exhibits a bimodal incidence and can also be seen in adults (55–65 years). 

Patients present with features of raised intracranial pressure, including headache that is a continuous dull-aching type and papilledema, visual impairment in the form of bitemporal hemianopia (Option B), and endocrinologic abnormalities, such as growth failure, hypothyroidism, diabetes insipidus, and delayed sexual maturation due to pituitary hypo-function.

MRI is the imaging modality of choice and they appear as calcified cystic masses in the supra-sellar region.

These tumors are usually large and heterogeneous and have solid and cystic components and a cholesterol-rich, thick, brownish-yellow fluid comparable to machine oil.

Treatment is usually by trans-cranial or trans-sphenoidal surgical resection. However, as these tumors have a high recurrence rate (Option C), surgery alone is not curative, and postoperative radiation (Option D) is always indicated.

questions.text:
A young patient presented with complaints of intermittent swelling of knees following strenuous exercise. There is no history of any mucosal bleeding. Laboratory findings are given. Which of the following monoclonal antibodies can be administered in this case?

Factor VIII - reduced
Partial thromboplastin time (PTT) - prolonged
questions.solution:
In the given scenario history of intermittent swelling of the knee joints and reduced factor VIII concentration is suggestive of hemophilic arthritis secondary to hemophilia A. The bispecific, humanized monoclonal antibody emicizumab can restore factor VIII activity in patients with hemophilia A.

Hemophilia A is an X-linked recessive disorder. It occurs due to a deficiency of clotting factor VIII. Symptoms include easy bruising, intramuscular hematomas, hemarthroses, hematuria, and bleeding from minor traumatic lacerations. Retroperitoneal haemorrhages can accumulate large volumes of blood and may cause a hypovolemic shock.

Laboratory findings:

  • Factor VIII - reduced
  • Activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) - prolonged
  • Platelet count- normal
  • Bleeding time- normal
  • Prothrombin time- normal
Severity The activity of a
specific clotting factor
Severe <1%
Moderate 1-5%
Mild >5%

Mild cases are treated with desmopressin acetate. Moderate to severe cases need replacement of factor VIII. Emicizumab- It is a humanized monoclonal antibody that restores factor VIII activity in patients with hemophilia. Once-weekly prophylactic subcutaneous injections of Emicizumab may be able to reduce the rate of bleeding in patients with or without factor VIII inhibitors.

Other Options:

Option B -  Trastuzumab is given to patients with breast cancer that are HER2 overexpressing.

Option C - Ipilimumab is a fully humanised IgG1 monoclonal antibody that inhibits cytotoxic T lymphocyte-Associated Protein-4 (CTLA-4). It is approved for the treatment of late-stage melanoma.

Option D - Natalizumab is a humanized monoclonal antibody against the α4 subunit of α4β1 integrin. It is used in multiple sclerosis.

questions.text: A 2-year-old baby weighing 15 kg was brought to the hospital with a history of loose stools. He is afebrile, and there is no blood in his stools. The baby is lethargic. On examination, the eyes are sunken and during the skin pinch test, the skin retraction took more than two seconds. On offering water the child does not show eagerness to drink and responds poorly. Which of the following is correct concerning the treatment of dehydration in this child?

choices.text: 600 ml to be given as IV in the first 1 hour
600 ml to be given as IV in the first  half hour
450 ml to be given as IV in the first half hour

questions.text: A woman who adopted a cat during her current pregnancy delivers a baby. The baby had features of chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus, and intracranial calcifications. Transplacental transmission is suspected. If she had been diagnosed early, what drug could have been administered to her to reduce the severity of the baby's symptoms?
questions.solution:
Spiramycin could have been administered to her during pregnancy to reduce the severity of the baby's symptoms. 

Toxoplasmosis refers to the infectious disease caused by the parasite Toxoplasma gondi. It comes under TORCH infections which consist of toxoplasmosis, others (syphilis, hepatitis B), rubella, cytomegalovirus, and herpes simplex.  It can be transmitted to humans by:

  • Ingestion of raw or inadequately cooked infected meat
  • Ingestion of oocysts through exposure to cat litter or soil
  • A newly infected pregnant woman passing the infection to her unborn fetus
  • Blood transfusion or organ transplantation 

Congenital toxoplasmosis occurs when a pregnant woman acquires the infection during gestation. The organism may cross to the fetus transplacentally or at the time of vaginal delivery. The severity of disease in the neonate is greater if the woman gets infected early in her pregnancy.

The classical triad of chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus, and intracranial calcifications can be seen in infected neonates. Other possible features include small size for gestational age, prematurity, jaundice, thrombocytopenia, hydrops fetalis, and perinatal death.

The diagnosis can be made by real-time PCR which provides quantitative results. Sabin-Feldman dye test, IgG indirect fluorescent antibody test, agglutination test, etc are the serological tests used.

 Pyrimethamine and sulfadiazine are also used in the treatment.  

Other options-

Option (A) and (B): Valganciclovir and Ganciclovir are therapeutic agents used to treat cytomegalovirus infections.

Option (D): Doxycycline is not used to treat toxoplasmosis.

Congenital rubella syndrome:

  • The triad of Gregg in congenital rubella syndrome includes:
    • Sensorineural hearing loss - Nerve deafness is the single most common finding among infants with congenital rubella syndrome
    • Congenital cataract
    • Congenital heart disease - The most common cardiac defect is patent ductus arteriosus
  • Maximum damage to the fetus occurs in the first trimester
  • Infection in the second trimester causes only deafness
  • If infection occurs after 16 weeks there are no major abnormalities
  • Diagnosis - Presence of IgM rubella antibodies in the infant shortly after birth or persistence of IgG antibodies for >6 months.

The given image shows blueberry muffin rash in an infant with congenital rubella syndrome

The image given below shows the salt and pepper fundus.

  • Causative organism belongs to the family Matonaviridae
  • Period of infectivity is -5 to +6 days after the onset of the rash
  • Droplet trasmission
  • The incubation period is 2-3 weeks
  • The rash appears on day 1
  • Forchheimer spots are seen, which are tiny, rose-colored lesions in the oropharynx
  • Associated with post-infectious thrombocytopenia
  • The most serious complication is encephalitis
  • Vaccination is done with the live attenuated RA 27/3 strain of the rubella

questions.text:
Choose the correct option regarding the given two statements about congenital cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection.

Statement A: The rate of transmission of CMV following primary maternal infection is greater than that following non-primary infection.

Statement B: Infants with congenital CMV infection due to non-primary maternal infection outnumber those with congenital CMV infection due to primary maternal infection.

choices.text: Statement A is true, Statement B is false.
Statement B is true, Statement A is false.

questions.solution:
Both statements A and B regarding CMV are true.

The rate of transmission of infection to the fetus in a mother who has a primary infection is about 30%, while in a mother with a nonprimary infection, it is 1-2%. Thus, Statement A is true.

However, in most populations, the total number of infants who have acquired an infection from a mother with nonprimary infection is 3-4 times more than infants who have acquired an infection from mothers with primary infection. Thus, Statement B is true.

Congenital infection with CMV is mostly asymptomatic, and symptomatic infections can occur in about 10% of newborns. Neonates who are asymptomatic at birth have a lesser risk of late sequelae.

The clinical manifestations are hepatosplenomegaly, petechial rashes, jaundice, chorioretinitis, and microcephaly. They can also develop hemorrhagic purpuric eruptions due to dermal erythropoiesis giving the appearance of a blueberry muffin baby. One of the long-term sequelae is sensorineural hearing loss. 

There is no definitive treatment for congenital CMV infection. Treatment with oral ganciclovir for 6 months could reduce the extent of hearing loss. Oral valganciclovir can also be used. Regular follow-ups should be done, particularly hearing screening tests.

questions.text: A newborn assessed 5 minutes after birth is found to have a  heart rate of 90 beats/min and irregular respiration. The baby coughed on inserting a nasal catheter and was moving all his limbs actively. The body was pink with blue extremities. What is the Apgar score in this newborn?
questions.solution:
The parameters in the given clinical scenario indicate that the Apgar score in this newborn is 7:

  • Appearance: Body is pink with blue extremities = 1
  • Pulse: 90 beats/min = 1
  • Grimace: Coughs on nasal catheter insertion = 2
  • Active motion: Moves all the limbs actively = 2
  • Respiratory effort - Irregular respiration = 1

The Apgar score is a systematic way of assessing the infant after birth at 1 and 5 minutes of life. It gives a maximum score of 10 which indicates the newborn is in the best possible condition.

Scores between 0-3 require immediate resuscitation. Changes in the Apgar scores denote the response of the infant to resuscitation. If the score at 5 minutes remains less than 7, the infant should be assessed again every 5 minutes for the next 20 minutes.

Causes for low Apgar score are:

  • Fetal distress
  • Prematurity
  • Drugs like analgesics, narcotics, sedatives, magnesium sulfate
  • Acute cerebral trauma
  • Precipitous delivery
  • Airway obstruction (choanal atresia)  
  • Congenital pneumonia or sepsis
  • Hemorrhage- hypovolemia

False-negative Apgar score is seen in maternal acidosis and high fetal catecholamine levels.

questions.text: A 2-day-old male infant with a birth weight of 3kg presents with respiratory distress and cyanosis. On examination, SpO2-70% and BP-60/40mmHg. An echocardiogram reveals hypoplastic left heart syndrome. Which of the following structures is not affected in this condition?
questions.solution:
The left atrium is not affected in hypoplastic left heart syndrome. The other three options - left ventricle, mitral valve, and aorta are hypoplastic.

The term hypoplastic left heart is used to describe the underdevelopment of the left side of the heart: stenosis or atresia of the aortic and mitral valves, and hypoplasia of the left ventricular cavity and ascending aorta. Due to this abnormality, systemic circulation is affected. To compensate for this, ductus arteriosus plays a major role. 

Oxygenated blood returning from the lungs enters the left atrium via pulmonary veins. In the presence of atrial septal defect (ASD) or dilated foramen, the oxygenated blood from the left atrium mixes with the deoxygenated blood in the right atrium. Normally, with the intact ventricular septum, the right ventricular blood enters the pulmonary trunk, this blood also reaches the descending aorta via ductus arteriosus. Also, this blood flows retrogradely from the descending aorta into the ascending aorta and coronary arteries. Inadequate blood flow via systemic circulation is the major hemodynamic abnormality.

questions.text:
A 20-month-old child was diagnosed with severe acute malnutrition and was started on treatment. When can the child's treatment be considered complete?
  1. There is no edema for at least two weeks
  2. There is no edema for at least 4 weeks
  3. Weight for length reaches - 2 S.D or higher
  4. Mid-upper arm circumference is more than 12.5 cm
  5. Mid-upper arm circumference is more than 13.5 cm
questions.solution:
The correct answer is 1, 3 and 4.

A child with SAM may be considered to have completed treatment when:

  • There is no edema for at least 2 weeks +
  • Weight-for-height (or length) reaches -2 SD or higher or mid-upper-arm circumference is more than 12.5 cm.

Severe acute malnutrition (SAM) in children of ages 6 to 59 months is defined by WHO as any of the following:

  • Weight-for-length (or height) below −3 SD of the WHO Child Growth Standards.
  • Presence of bipedal edema
  • Mid-upper arm circumference <11.5 cm

Treatment: The general treatment involves 10 steps in 2 phases:

Phases: 

Initial stabilization phase :

(mnemonic: SHIELDED- Sugar deficiency(hypoglycemia), Hypothermia, Infection, ELectrolyte imbalance, DEhydration, Deficiency of nutrients)

  • Focuses on restoring homeostasis and treating medical conditions.
  • 2-7 days of inpatient treatment

Rehabilitation phase: 

  • Focuses on rebuilding wasted tissues
  • Takes several weeks

Steps:

  • Treat hypoglycemia (Blood glucose level<54 mg/dl): if symptomatic give 10% Dextrose IV 5ml/kg; Feeding should be initiated with starter F-75 (Formula with 75 kcal/100 ml of feed)
  • Treat hypothermia (axillary <35°C or 95°F): Skin-to-skin contact with care (“kangaroo technique”) or dress in warmer clothes, cover head, wrap in a warmed blanket, and provide indirect heat.
  • Treat dehydration: Hydrate with ReSoMal - Rehydration solution for malnutrition (45 mmol Na/L). It is a low-sodium rehydration solution for malnutrition.
  • Correct electrolyte imbalance: There is a deficit of potassium and magnesium and excess sodium. Give extra potassium (4 mmol/kg/day) and magnesium (0.6 mmol/kg/day) for at least 2 weeks.
  • Treat infection: Starting on the first day, give broad-spectrum antibiotics to all children.
  • Correct micronutrient deficiencies:
    • Do not give iron in the stabilization phase, because excess iron leads to free radical injury. Give iron 3 mg/kg/day once the child starts gaining weight after the stabilization phase.
    • Give vitamin A on day 1. Repeat on day 2 and day 14 if there is presence of xeropthalmia.
    • Folic acid 1 mg (5 mg on day 1)
    • Zinc (2 mg/kg/day)
    • Copper (0.3 mg/kg/day)
  • Start cautious feeding : Give 8 to 12 small feeds of F75 to provide 130 mL/kg/day,100 kcal/kg/day, and 1 to 1.5 g protein/kg/day.
  • Rehabilitation: The indications of entry to this phase are reduced/minimal edema and the return of appetite.
    • Beginning of feeding.
    • After 3 days, the transition to energy-dense feeding
    • Stimulation of emotional and sensorial development
    • Transfer to home-based diet

questions.text: In which of the following cases will you advise the mother to hold her baby in the method shown below, immediately after delivery?

choices.text: Baby born at 34 weeks of gestation with birth weight of 1.2kg
Hemodynamically stable term baby with birth weight of 2.8 kg
Hemodynamically unstable preterm with birth weight of 2 kg
Baby born at 33 weeks of gestation with a birth weight of 2 kg

questions.solution:
The image shows Kangaroo Mother Care (KMC) can be done in a baby born at 33 weeks of gestation with a birth weight of 2 kg.

KMC was introduced for the prevention of neonatal hypothermia in low birth weight/ premature newborns.

Eligibility criteria for KMC:

It is indicated for all hemodynamically stable low birth weight babies (option C). Short sessions of KMC can be initiated in babies on medical treatment like IV fluids or oxygen therapy. Initiation of KMC can vary with the birth weight of the baby.

  • Birth weight <1200 g - It may take days to weeks for initiation of KMC (Option A)
  • Birth weight =1200-1800 g - Only a few days may be taken before KMC initiation
  • Birth weight >1800 g - KMC can be initiated immediately after birth

It has 4 components—

  • Skin-to-skin positioning of the newborn on the mother’s chest.
  • Adequate nutrition through breastfeeding.
  • Early discharge and ambulatory care.
  • Support for mother and family for child care.

Evidence shows that-

  • It is at least equivalent to incubators, in terms of safety and thermal protection (measured by mortality)
  • Reduces severe morbidity by way of facilitating breastfeeding
  • Humanization of neonatal care
  • Promoted bonding between mother and child

All mothers without any serious illness can provide KMC.

Positioning for KMC: The baby is placed between the mother's breasts in an upright position. The hips are abducted and flexed in the frog position and the arms are also flexed. The abdomen of the baby should be at the level of the mother's epigastrium. In this position, the mother's breathing would stimulate the baby and prevent the development of apnea.

The duration of KMC should be gradually increased from short sessions of more than one hour to 24 hours a day.

KMC is not necessary once the baby attains 2500 g of weight or 37 weeks of gestation (Option B).

Note: 

Incubatory care, feeding via nasal catheter, and prevention of infection are part of intensive care for low birthweight babies.

questions.text: A 1-month-old infant diagnosed with primary adrenal insufficiency presented with failure to thrive, recurrent emesis, and hepatosplenomegaly. Bilateral adrenal calcification was noted radiologically. Which of the following enzymes is deficient in this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of an infant with primary adrenal insufficiency with hepatosplenomegaly, recurrent vomiting, and bilateral adrenal calcification is suggestive of Wolman's disease. This disease is caused by the deficiency of the enzyme acid lipase.

Wolman's disease:

  • Rare lipid storage disorder caused by a deficiency of lysosomal acid lipase, leading to the accumulation of cholesterol esters and triglycerides in the most visceral organs
  • Presents in the first few weeks of life with failure to thrive, vomiting, abdominal distention, steatorrhea, hepatosplenomegaly, and hyperlipidemia with extensive bilateral calcifications of the adrenal glands.

Other options:

Option A: 11β-hydroxylase deficiency causes congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH). It is the most common enzyme deficiency leading to childhood hypertension.

Option B: Deficiency of the enzyme acid maltase/α-1,4-glucosidase causes Pompe's disease, a type II glycogen storage disorder. It is a rapidly progressive disorder that results in hypotonia (floppy infant), skeletal muscle weakness, hepatomegaly, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, and macroglossia; chest x-ray image shows cardiomegaly.

Option D: Deficiency of P450 oxidoreductase (POR) results in congenital anomalies collectively referred to as Antley-Bixler syndrome. These include deficiencies of 17-hydroxylase and 21-hydroxylase, which leads to congenital adrenal hyperplasia, along with other congenital anomalies.

questions.text: A young girl presents to you with delayed puberty. On examination, you notice the characteristic finding shown in the picture below. Apart from this, she has a shield-shaped chest. Investigations revealed the presence of normal gonads and pulmonary valvular stenosis. Which of the following is not true regarding the condition?

choices.text: It is most commonly due to mutation of chromosome 12.

questions.solution:
The clinical diagnosis based on features of a short, webbed neck, shield chest, normal gonads, and pulmonary valvular stenosis is Noonan syndrome. Noonan syndrome affects both sexes with normal karyotypes.

Noonan syndrome follows an autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance. It involves mutations of the components of the RAS mitogen-activated protein kinase pathway (RAS-MAPK) pathway. The most common of these mutations is that of PTPN11, which encodes a protein tyrosine phosphatase on chromosome 12. (Option A)

  • Down-slanting palpebral fissure (antimongoloid slant)
  • Pectus carinatum or pectus excavatum.
  • Hypertelorism

  • Leukemia (Juvenile chronic myelogenous leukemia)

  • High-frequency sensorineural hearing loss is common. (Option D)
  • Short stature, webbed neck, low set ears, cubitus valgus (similarities with Turner syndrome)
  • Ptosis, micrognathia, clinodactyly, delayed puberty.

questions.text: A woman just delivered a term baby girl and both the mother and the child are doing well following the cesarean delivery. Benign respiratory distress in a newborn with a chest X-ray showing fluid in the interlobar fissure is indicative of transient tachypnoea of newborn (TTN), also known as retained fetal lung liquid syndrome.

It is more common after a term, cesarean delivery and is due to the delayed clearance of the lung fluid from the interstitium into the pulmonary lymphatics.

The management of TTN is supportive oxygen therapy in the range of 30-40% and observation. 

Other findings of chest x-ray imaging are prominent (perihilar) pulmonary vascular markings, increased interstitial markings, and a “wet silhouette” around the heart.

Option C : Meconium aspiration syndrome commonly affects post-term babies and only 15% of term deliveries. Also the Xray here will show patchy inflitrates, atelectasis and bulla in some areas.

Option D : Brochopulmonary dysplasia usually occurs following more than 40% concentration oxygen administration which is toxic to lungs.The Xray shows a spongelike appearance here.

questions.text: A 6-year-old girl is brought to the OPD with shortness of breath during exercise. Diagnosis of ASD is confirmed. Identify the true statement about her condition.

choices.text: Ostium primum ASD presents with right ventricular hypertrophy
Ostium secundum ASD presents with left ventricular hypertrophy
Ostium secundum defect is more common
Ostium primum defect is present in upper part of atrial septum

questions.solution:
Ostium secundum ASD is the most common type of ASD.

ASD is characterised by an abnormal opening in the atrial septum allowing communication between the right and left atria. There are four types based on their location within the septum:

  • Secundum ASD - most common, usually an isolated abnormality
  • Primum ASD - associated with abnormal mitral valve leaflet (partial AV septal defect)
  • Sinus venous - is located at the junction of the superior vena cava and right atrium. Associated with anomalous right pulmonary venous return to the SVC or RA
  • Coronary sinus type ASD - also called unroofed coronary sinus

Option A: Ostium primum ASD presents with left ventricular hypertrophy.

questions.text: A 3-year-old unimmunized child is brought to the emergency room with high-grade fever, drooling of saliva, and dysphagia. Auscultation revealed inspiratory stridor. His lateral X-ray of neck is given below. The next best step in his management is?

choices.text: Secure airway and start empirical IV ceftriaxone
Give antipyretics and reassure the patient

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of high-grade fever, drooling, dysphagia, and inspiratory stridor along with the lateral X-ray neck showing the thumb sign suggests acute epiglottitis. The next best step in his management is to secure airway and start empirical IV ceftriaxone.

Acute epiglottitis is an acute rapidly progressive inflammatory condition of supra-glottic structures, i.e. epiglottis, aryepiglottic folds, and arytenoid. It is also known as supraglottic laryngitis and is a medical emergency. 

It commonly affects children aged 2–7 years. The most common organism responsible for this is Haemophilus influenzae type B (Hib). 

Clinical features include high-grade fever, dysphagia, drooling of saliva, sore throat, dyspnea, and inspiratory stridor.The patient usually adopts a tripod position by leaning forward on his arms and has his neck extended with his chin up and breathing through the mouth. Airway obstruction occurs due to inflammation and edema of the surrounding structures. 

The direct laryngoscopic shows an inflamed and swollen epiglottis that has a characteristic cherry-red-colored appearance. A lateral X-ray of the neck shows swollen epiglottis giving an appearance called the thumb sign (shown below). 

Treatment includes: 

  • Immediate hospitalization 
  • Securing airway by endotracheal or nasotracheal intubation or by tracheostomy, irrespective of the degree of respiratory obstruction
  • Empirical management by third-generation cephalosporins (cefotaxime, ceftriaxone) or ampicillin
  • Dexamethasone may be given to reduce pharyngeal edema
  • Humidified oxygen can also be given

questions.text: A 3-week-old infant was brought to you with complaints of projectile, non-bilious vomiting after feeding. On examination, you were able to palpate a firm ovoid mass in the right upper abdominal quadrant. You suspect Infantile Hypertrophic Pyloric Stenosis and barium contrast studies were performed. The barium study can demonstrate all the following signs, except ______.
questions.solution:
Cervix sign is a USG finding seen in a patient with hypertrophic pyloric stenosis and not a finding of barium study.

The investigation of choice to confirm the diagnosis is ultrasound which shows hypoechoic, thickened pyloric muscle and an elongated pyloric canal. The sonographic appearance of the hypertrophied pylorus resembles that of the uterine cervix and is referred to as the cervix sign and the double-layered, hypertrophic mucosa protruding into the stomach is called the nipple sign.

If ultrasound is inconclusive, contrast studies (barium) are performed, which may demonstrate:

  • An elongated pyloric channel (string sign),
  • A bulge of the pyloric muscle into the antrum (shoulder sign)
  • Parallel streaks of barium are seen in the narrowed channel, producing a “double tract sign.”

The ultrasound image shows the cervix sign.

questions.text: Patients with all of the following conditions can develop precocious puberty, except _____.
questions.solution:
The Prader Willi syndrome presents with delayed puberty.

Prader Willi syndrome is caused due to genomic imprinting, where there is the deletion of a part of the paternal chromosome 15. The clinical features include hypotonia, childhood obesity, growth failure, dysmorphic facial features, delayed puberty, and behavioral problems.

Precocious puberty is defined by the onset of secondary sexual characteristics before the age of 8 years in females and 9 years in males.

The causes of complete isosexual precocious puberty, which is GnRH dependent include:

  • Idiopathic true precocious puberty
  • Central nervous system disorders such as hypothalamic hamartomas, encephalitis, and brain abscess.

The causes of incomplete isosexual precocious puberty are:

  • Gonadotropin (GnRH) secreting tumors
  • Increased androgen secretion by adrenal or testis such as in congenital adrenal hyperplasia
  • Ovarian cysts and estrogen secreting ovarian or adrenal neoplasms
  • McCune Albright syndrome

The causes of contrasexual precocity include feminization in males due to conditions such as adrenal neoplasms and chorioepithelioma, and virilization in females due to conditions such as congenital adrenal hyperplasia, virilizing adrenal neoplasms and iatrogenic exposure to androgens.
