questions.text: A mother brings her 2-year-old child to the pediatrician after the baby developed a high fever and rashes over the body. She says that the baby initially had a very high fever, running nose, and redness of eyes. After 3 days, the fever came down, but the baby started to develop rashes. It initially started on the trunk and then spread to the face, neck, and other parts of the body. On examination, you notice multiple erythematous and maculopapular rashes over the body of the baby. Oral examination reveals lesions at the uvulopalatoglossal junction. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis based on the given clinical scenario is roseola infantum. The pattern of fever, the timing and pattern of spread of the rashes, and the presence of lesions at the uvulopalatoglossal junction favor the diagnosis.

Roseola infantum (also called sixth disease and exanthem subitum) is an infection caused by the human herpesvirus 6 (HHV- 6)and human herpesvirus 7 (HHV-7). The majority of the cases are caused by HHV-6. 

It is characterized by the abrupt onset of high fever, which may be accompanied by a runny nose, redness of eyes, etc. The fever usually comes down after 3 days followed by the appearance of faint pink or rose-colored nonpruritic morbilliform rash. The rashes first appear in the trunk and then spread to the rest of the body. In a few people, there might also be ulcers at the uvulopalatoglossal junction, which are called Nagayama spots.

Hydration and antipyretics are recommended for the management.

Other options 

Option A: Measles is characterized by prodromal symptoms like fever, running nose conjunctival congestion, etc. On the second day, gray white-colored sand-like lesions appear over the mucosa opposite to the lower second molars. These are called Koplik spots. The rash appears on the 4th day. It first appears behind the ears, along the hairline, and then spreads to the face, neck, and other parts of the body.

Option C: Chickenpox also presents with fever and rash. The rash appears within 24 to 48 hours after the appearance of the fever. It first starts on the trunk and then spreads to the face and other parts of the body. It evolves into clear fluid-filled vesicles, clouded vesicles, and then crusted vesicles. Several skin lesions with different sizes and different stages of evolution can be seen simultaneously.

Option D: Rubella presents with fever, rash, and lymphadenopathy. The pink maculopapular rash first appears on the face and then spreads to trunk and extremities within 24 hours. Enanthem on the soft palate can be observed which are called Forchheimer spots.

questions.text: A dried blood sample after heel prick is being sent for measurement of TSH level in a neonate. Which of the following is an ideal time to collect the sample after birth?
questions.solution:
The ideal time to perform a dried blood spot (DBS) test for congenital hypothyroidism (CH) is between 2 and 4 days (Day 3) after birth. This is because TSH levels are elevated in the first 1 or 2 days after birth due to a physiological neonatal TSH surge. If the test is performed too early, it may result in a false positive. 

Most screening programs measure TSH levels first to detect primary hypothyroidism. TSH is high in all babies when done immediately after birth. Therefore, the test is done between days 2-5. TSH-based screening approach has higher sensitivity than T4 based approach. However, rarer diseases such as central hypothyroidism might not be detected in this approach. T4 based approach can identify children with central hypothyroidism but misses the cases of compensated hypothyroidism. 

Due to the presence of maternal thyroxine, congenital hypothyroidism can be asymptomatic during the first week of life. Therefore, neonatal screening should be done for early diagnosis and treatment. Blood from a heel prick is placed on a filter paper card and sent to the screening lab. 

Symptoms of congenital hypothyroidism usually manifest one week after birth. The clinical features include lethargy, hypothermia, constipation, coarse facies, umbilical hernia, hypotonia, and prolonged jaundice. X-ray shows delayed skeletal maturation, stippled epiphyses, and wormian bones(skull). Treatment should be started early to prevent neurological abnormalities.

questions.text: A 3-hour-old neonate with apnea has been on bag and mask ventilation for the last 30 seconds. She has now started taking spontaneous breaths. The heart rate is still at 100–110/min. What is your next step?
questions.solution:
As per the NRP algorithm, at any time during resuscitation, if the HR > 100 and spontaneous breathing resumes then discontinue ventilation.

The components of NRP resuscitation include the following: (TABCD)

  • Temperature- maintain between 36.5 and 37.5oC
  • Airway- "sniffing" position, clear secretions if needed
  • Breathing- tactile stimulation, PPV (40–60 breaths/min), ETT
  • Circulation- chest compressions:ventilation ratio (3:1 = 90:30; lower 1/3rd sternum; two thumb technique preferred)
  • Drugs- Epinephrine, volume expanders 

Algorithm states:

  • HR <100/min + no respirations →  Positive pressure ventilation (PPV)
  • No response with PPV → Endotracheal intubation (ET)
  • HR <60/min → Chest compressions
  • No response to chest compressions → Epinephrine

questions.text: A patient presents to the OPD with complaints of nausea, vomiting, and severe muscle pain after exercise. The exercise intolerance worsens after a carbohydrate rich meal. Investigations revealed a hemolytic anemia type of picture. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario history of worsening of exercise intolerance after a carbohydrate diet with laboratory investigations revealing hemolytic anemia picture is suggestive of Tarui's disease.

The clinical picture of Tarui's disease is similar to McArdle's disease. However, exercise intolerance is more severe and there is no second wind phenomenon in Tarui's disease. The exercise intolerance worsens after a carbohydrate-rich meal in Tauri's disease as there is a deficiency of phosphofructokinase and thus glucose is not metabolized. The ingested glucose prevents lipolysis, thereby depriving muscle of fatty acid and ketone substrates. In McArdle's disease exercise tolerance improves on glucose infusion as glucose can be metabolized unlike in Tauri's disease.

Tarui's disease is a type VII glycogen storage disorder that results due to the deficiency of phosphofructokinase. Phosphofructokinase is a key regulatory enzyme of glycolysis and is necessary for the ATP-dependent conversion of fructose-6-phosphate to fructose-1,6-diphosphate.

Some cases may present with hereditary nonspherocytic hemolytic anemia as indicated by elevated serum bilirubin and elevated reticulocyte count. Demonstration of defective enzymes in the muscles is required to establish the diagnosis.

There is no specific treatment for Tarui's disease. Strenuous exercise should be avoided to prevent acute episodes of muscle cramps and myoglobinuria. A ketogenic diet helps in clinical improvement.

questions.text: A 5-year-old girl is brought by her mother to the OPD with complaints of increased urination, and increased water consumption. On examination, there was exophthalmos. Her 24-hour urine osmolarity was 240 mOsm/L and her Na+ level was 152mEq/L. Her skull and spine appear as below. Which immunohistochemical marker would likely be positive in this condition?
questions.solution:
Based on the given clinical scenario, it is found that the patient has a triad of diabetes insipidus, and exophthalmos along with an X-ray showing lytic lesions in the skull which are all suggestive of Hand Schuller Christian disease. The positive immunohistochemical marker seen in this condition is Langerin (CD207).

Diabetes insipidus (DI) is a syndrome characterised by the excretion of abnormally large volumes of dilute urine. The 24-hour urine volume exceeds 40 mL/ kg body weight. The 24-hour urine osmolarity is <280 mOsm/L. There will be a slight increase in plasma osmolarity/sodium that stimulates thirst(polydipsia). 

Langerhans Cell Histiocytosis (LCH):

A spectrum of clinical diseases associated with the proliferation of Langerhans cells. These cells contain distinctive granules, seen on electron microscopy – Rod-shaped tennis racket or Birbeck granules. On light microscopy, Langerhans cells with folded or grooved nuclei and moderately abundant pale cytoplasm are mixed with a few eosinophils are seen.

Unifocal Langerhans cell histiocytosis (eosinophilic granuloma)is a localized form of histiocytosis, a benign lesion of proliferating Langerhans' cells. It is the least severe of the histiocytosis syndromes and is characterized by lytic lesions of one or more bones. Seen in older patients, mostly affecting the skeletal system.

Hand-Schuller-Christian disease (Multifocal LCH): Common in 2 - 6 years of life. The characteristic triad consists of:

  • Bony lytic skull lesions
  • Exophthalmos
  • Diabetes insipidus

Immunohistochemical markers include HLA-DR, S-100, CD1a, and langerin (CD207). 

The electron microscopic picture of the Langerhans cells containing distinctive granules (Rod-shaped tennis racket or Birbeck granules) is shown below.

Letterer-Siwe disease (Acute disseminated LCH) - Affects children before 3 years of age. Features include:

  • Seborrheic lesions,
  • Anaemia, thrombocytopenia
  • Recurrent infections
  • The clinical course is usually rapidly fatal

questions.text: A 5-month-old infant with a birth weight of 3.5 kg was brought by her mother with complaints of excessive crying and no neck holding. Also, there was a complaint of constipation which has not resolved on treatment. On examination, the posterior fontanelle was not fused, and genitourinary malformations were noted on ultrasound. On lab investigations, TSH was elevated and T4 levels were low. For the given clinical scenario, identify the most likely mutation that can occur.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of excessive crying, lack of neck holding, constipation, and non-fusion of the posterior fontanelle suggests congenital hypothyroidism. Congenital hypothyroidism associated with genitourinary malformations is associated with a mutation in the PAX8 gene.

Non-goitrous hypothyroidism is known to be associated with TSHR, PAX8, and TSHB gene defects. 

Congenital hypothyroidism is the most common preventable cause of intellectual disability. Congenital hypothyroidism is mostly asymptomatic at birth and is detected mainly by the neonatal screening of TSH levels in the first few weeks of life. Clinical features present after maternal thyroxine wanes. Thyroid dysgenesis is considered the most common cause of congenital hypothyroidism in India.

The clinical features of congenital hypothyroidism include a puffy face, enlarged fontanelles, macroglossia, prolonged jaundice, lethargy, and a history of poor feeding. The absence of distal femoral and proximal tibial epiphysis denotes the onset of congenital hypothyroidism. These epiphyses are normally present at birth. Epiphyseal dysgenesis, wherein there are multiple foci of ossification in the epiphyses, is common. X-rays of the skull reveal enlarged sella, large fontanelles, wide sutures, and intersutural (wormian) bones. 

Management: Thyroxine replacement is started immediately after diagnosis of congenital hypothyroidism.  Thyroxine is initiated at 10-15 pg/kg/day. The thyroxine dose should be adjusted to achieve free T4 levels in the upper normal range for the age.

Other options:

Option B: BRCA mutation in breast cancer.

Option C: p53 mutation in ovarian, colon, and many other cancers.

Option D: KRAS mutation in adenocarcinoma colon.
